elements.html:
Reading Comprehension Study

Welcome!

In this study we are trying to find out how readers interpret a specific group of words that are commonly used to describe things and situations in newspaper articles, forum discussions, chats, etc.

You will see 10 randomly selected articles about different topics published in the New York Times during the past 30 years. In each article, the author will at some point refer to some “issue” or “fact”, and your job will be to outline what specifically the author is talking about.

Instructions – Please Read Carefully

There is exactly one target phrase per text such as this issue in the example below. Please start by reading each of the articles from the beginning up to the highlighted target phrase.

Egypt Warned U.S. of Terror, Mubarak Says

President Hosni Mubarak of Egypt said today that the United States could have prevented the bombing of the World Trade Center if American officials had heeded his country’s warnings about an Islamic fundamentalist network in the United States.

[…]

Concerning the Middle East peace talks, Mr. Mubarak said he would “try to do my best with the President” to persuade him to urge the Israelis to speed the return of about 400 Palestinians deported to Lebanon in December.

This issue has frozen the peace talks. Washington has invited all the participants to a new round of talks on April 20, but the Palestinian delegation is demanding additional concessions on the deportee issue before attending.

[…]

As soon as you feel confident you got what the author is talking about, we’d like you to write down a description of what the target phrase refers to, either as

  • ✓ A full sentence: “About 400 Palestinians have been deported to Lebanon in December and Israel should speed their return”
  • ✓ A key phrase: “the issue that a large group of Palestinians has been sent to Lebanon”, or
  • ✓ A segment copied from the text: “the return of about 400 Palestinians deported to Lebanon in December”

There are no length restrictions, but please try to keep your answers as concise and informative as possible, so you should avoid

  • ✗ “I have no idea”: If you are really unsure, please try to come up with a few keywords like “Israel, Middle East peace talks, deportation” and leave a note in the comment field that this was a tough one.
  • ✗ “The Israeli–Palestinian conflict”: Too general for the given example, as the author is referring to a particular issue.
  • ✗ “he wants some people to be sent somewhere”: This is too vague.

Finally, we’d like you to rate how difficult it was to understand the target phrase: Was it clear right away? Or did you have to think about it a lot, re-read (parts of) the text, or remained unsure altogether?

You’re welcome to leave an optional comment if you found an example particularly difficult, interesting, ambiguous, or noteworthy in any other way. This is very useful information for us!

Important Notes

  • Do not refresh your browser or use the browser navigation buttons during the study as your progress will be lost.
  • Before you start, please switch off phone/e-mail/music etc. so you can focus on the task.
  • If you have questions or problems, don’t hesitate to contact us.

Let’s get started!

WHO'S NOT IN THE HALL OF FAME WHO SHOULD BE

July 19, 1987

In this era of superstars (with super statistics and super salaries to match), we tend to lose sight of the fact that the Hall of Fame at Cooperstown was originally intended to honor not only players of exceptional ability, but those of exemplary virtue and integrity as well. It is with this fact in mind that I state my case for the inclusion of Gil Hodges in the Hall of Fame. (TEXT TRUNCATED)

© The New York Times Company
